title: Kieran Tierney
text:
Kieran Tierney (born 5 June 1997) is a Scottish professional <a href="association%20footballer">footballer</a> who plays as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29%23Full-back">left-back</a> or <a href="centre-back">centre-back</a> for <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> club <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a> and the <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland national team</a>.
Tierney came through the <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a> youth system and made his first team debut in April 2015, and his full international debut in March 2016. He joined Arsenal in August 2019 for a fee reported at £25 million, a <a href="Football%20records%20in%20Scotland%23Record%20transfer%20fees%20received">record amount</a> both for a Scottish national and for a player from the Scottish league.
Club career.
Early life and youth football.
Born in <a href="Douglas%2C%20Isle%20of%20Man">Douglas</a> on the <a href="Isle%20of%20Man">Isle of Man</a>, Tierney moved to <a href="Wishaw">Wishaw</a> in Scotland aged 10 months. He supported <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a> as a child and signed for the club when he was 7 years old. He was educated at <a href="Motherwell">Motherwell</a> schools St Brendan's RC Primary and <a href="Our%20Lady%27s%20High%20School%2C%20Motherwell">Our Lady's High</a> (one year group behind fellow footballers, twins <a href="Nicky%20Cadden">Nicky</a> and <a href="Chris%20Cadden">Chris Cadden</a>) then attended <a href="St%20Ninian%27s%20High%20School%2C%20Kirkintilloch">St Ninian's High School, Kirkintilloch</a>, which has a development partnership with Celtic. He has spoken of his hope of emulating the late <a href="Tommy%20Gemmell">Tommy Gemmell</a>, a member of the <a href="Lisbon%20Lions">Lisbon Lions</a> team who also grew up in Wishaw (specifically, <a href="Craigneuk">Craigneuk</a>) and played in the same position.
He progressed through the various youth ranks and earned a reputation as a dependable wide player in the club's <a href="Celtic%20F.C.%20Reserve%20and%20Youth%20squads">development squad</a>, both in defence and attack. He travelled with the first team squad on a pre-season trip to Finland in August 2014, and made his debut in a friendly against <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a> there. Although Celtic lost, Tierney described his first appearance for the first team as a "dream come true". He continued to play in the development squad throughout 2014–15, and in October 2014 during a <a href="SPFL%20Development%20League">Development League</a> match against <a href="Heart%20of%20Midlothian%20F.C.%20Under-20s%20and%20Academy">Heart of Midlothian</a> he scored a goal from the edge of his own penalty box.
Celtic.
2015–16: Debut and breakthrough.
Tierney made his competitive senior debut for Celtic on 22 April 2015, coming on as an 81st-minute substitute in a <a href="Scottish%20Premiership">Scottish Premiership</a> match against <a href="Dundee%20F.C.">Dundee</a>. He made one further first team appearance that season, playing over an hour in a league match away at <a href="St%20Johnstone%20F.C.">St Johnstone</a>.
Tierney enjoyed a breakthrough season in <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20in%20Scottish%20football">2015–16</a>, appearing in over 30 matches and displacing the more experienced <a href="Emilio%20Izaguirre">Emilio Izaguirre</a> as first-choice left back. For his performances he was awarded with both the <a href="PFA%20Scotland%20Young%20Player%20of%20the%20Year">Players'</a> and <a href="SFWA%20Young%20Player%20of%20the%20Year">Writers'</a> Young Player annual awards, while Celtic also won the league title. Despite interest from <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> clubs, Tierney signed a new five-year contract on 24 June 2016, keeping him at Parkhead until 2021. After making his first appearances in the <a href="2016%E2%80%9317%20UEFA%20Champions%20League%20group%20stage%23Group%20C">group stage</a> of the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a>, Tierney suffered ankle ligament damage during training on 27 October 2016 and was initially ruled out of action for two months. During the layoff, which caused him to miss the <a href="2016%20Scottish%20League%20Cup%20Final%20%28November%29">League Cup Final</a>, he received treatment on a recurring shoulder injury and attended several Celtic matches as a typical supporter in the company of his childhood friends.
2017–2019: Back-to-back domestic trebles.
On 22 January 2017, after missing three months, he made his long-awaited return to the Celtic team in a <a href="Scottish%20Cup">Scottish Cup</a> tie against <a href="Albion%20Rovers%20F.C.">Albion Rovers</a>. Tierney was crowned PFA Scotland Young Player of the Year for the second consecutive season on 7 May, making him the first to achieve this since <a href="Craig%20Levein">Craig Levein</a> in 1986. He suffered a jaw injury early in the <a href="2017%20Scottish%20Cup%20Final">2017 Scottish Cup Final</a> and had to be substituted for treatment. Celtic won the match 2–1 to complete a <a href="Treble%20%28association%20football%29%23Domestic%20trebles">domestic treble</a> and <a href="List%20of%20unbeaten%20football%20club%20seasons">undefeated season</a>. In spite of his lengthy injury absence, he featured in 40 matches during the campaign.
On 8 August 2017, Tierney was named as <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">captain</a> while also moving to <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29%23Central%20defender">central defender</a> to command a back line of teenagers in a <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Scottish%20League%20Cup%23Second%20round">Scottish League Cup</a> fixture against <a href="Kilmarnock%20F.C.">Kilmarnock</a>; Celtic won the game 5–0, with Tierney providing an <a href="Assist%20%28football%29">assist</a> and scoring with a "wonderful strike" from 40 yards. On 30 October, a week after scoring in an important <a href="2017%E2%80%9318%20Scottish%20Premiership">league</a> victory away to closest challengers <a href="Aberdeen%20F.C.">Aberdeen</a>, he extended his contract with Celtic until 2023.
By the end of the season, he had collected further personal accolades—winning both the <a href="PFA%20Scotland%20Young%20Player%20of%20the%20Year">Players'</a> and <a href="SFWA%20Young%20Player%20of%20the%20Year">Writers'</a> Young Player awards for the third campaign in succession—and performed a major role in securing a historic 'double treble' for the club, making more than 50 appearances and playing the entirety of the domestic cup finals, both being 2–0 wins over <a href="Motherwell%20F.C.">Motherwell</a>. Tierney played in Celtic's victory over Aberdeen in the <a href="2018%20Scottish%20League%20Cup%20Final">2018 Scottish League Cup Final</a> on 2 December 2018. Soon afterwards a hip injury meant that he was ruled out of action, returning on 24 February 2019. He then suffered from a hernia, which subsequently required surgery.
Arsenal.
2019–2021: FA Cup win and injuries.
On 8 August 2019, Tierney signed for <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a> club <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a>, for a reported £25 million fee. Tierney missed the early part of the 2019–20 season, having undergone a double hernia operation in May 2019. He made his first-team debut for Arsenal in a 5–0 win against <a href="Nottingham%20Forest%20F.C.">Nottingham Forest</a> in the <a href="EFL%20Cup">EFL Cup</a> on 24 September. Tierney assisted the first goal in a 4–0 home win against <a href="Standard%20Li%C3%A8ge">Standard Liège</a> scored by <a href="Gabriel%20Martinelli">Gabriel Martinelli</a> a week later. He made his first appearance in the Premier League on 27 October, in a 2–2 draw with <a href="Crystal%20Palace%20F.C.">Crystal Palace</a>. His season was further disrupted after suffering a dislocated shoulder in the game against West Ham United.
Tierney's impressive performances for Arsenal following the resumption of the Premier League after the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a> saw him receive Arsenal's Player of the Month award for June. He scored his first goal for Arsenal on 26 July, in a 3–2 win against <a href="Watford%20F.C.">Watford</a> on the final day of the 2019–20 Premier League season. On 1 August 2020, Tierney was selected to start in the <a href="2020%20FA%20Cup%20Final">FA Cup Final</a> against Chelsea, as Arsenal won their 14th FA Cup.
On 28 August 2020, Tierney was in the starting 11 in the <a href="2020%20FA%20Community%20Shield">2020 FA Community Shield</a>, which Arsenal clinched a 5–4 victory over <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a> in the penalty shootout after the match was 1–1 after 90 minutes. On 2 January 2021, Tierney scored the opening goal in a 4–0 away league win over <a href="West%20Bromwich%20Albion%20F.C.">West Bromwich Albion</a> and later assisted the final goal, scored by <a href="Alexandre%20Lacazette">Alexandre Lacazette</a>. His stunning strike was subsequently voted the January Goal of the Month on the Arsenal official website. On 25 February, he scored a goal in a 3–2 win over <a href="S.L.%20Benfica">Benfica</a> in the <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">Europa League</a> round of 32, making him the first Scotsman to score for Arsenal in a European competition since <a href="Willie%20Young%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201951%29">Willie Young</a> in March 1980. In June 2021, he signed a long-term contract with Arsenal.
International career.
Tierney played for Scotland at <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland U18</a> and <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland U19</a> levels. He had also considered playing for the <a href="Ellan%20Vannin%20football%20team">Ellan Vannin team</a> that represents the Isle of Man when the <a href="ConIFA">ConIFA</a> World Cup competition was being held.
Tierney received his first call-up to the senior <a href="Scotland%20national%20football%20team">Scotland</a> squad on 10 March 2016 for a friendly against <a href="Denmark%20national%20football%20team">Denmark</a>. Tierney played for the first half of the match, which Scotland won 1–0 at <a href="Hampden%20Park">Hampden Park</a>; he was replaced at the break by his Celtic teammate <a href="Charlie%20Mulgrew">Charlie Mulgrew</a>.
Due to his greater adaptability compared to fellow left-back <a href="Andrew%20Robertson">Andrew Robertson</a>, Tierney was deployed at right-back in Scotland's matches against <a href="Slovenia%20national%20football%20team">Slovenia</a>, <a href="Lithuania%20national%20football%20team">Lithuania</a> and <a href="Slovakia%20national%20football%20team">Slovakia</a>, and on the left of a three-man defence in the fixture at home to <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> during <a href="2018%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%26amp%3Bnbsp%3B%E2%80%93%20UEFA%20Group%20F">World Cup qualifiers</a> in 2017.
Tierney was selected as Scotland captain for a friendly match against <a href="Netherlands%20national%20football%20team">the Netherlands</a> in November 2017, where he played as a central defender in a 1–0 defeat.
In October 2018, Tierney scored a decisive <a href="own%20goal">own goal</a> in a 2–1 loss to <a href="Israel%20national%20football%20team">Israel</a> in a <a href="UEFA%20Nations%20League">UEFA Nations League</a> fixture. Speaking after the game, Robertson said that both he and Tierney were being played out of position in the 3–5–2 system adopted by <a href="Alex%20McLeish">Alex McLeish</a> to accommodate both players.
In November 2019, Tierney withdrew from the Scotland squad ahead of their <a href="UEFA%20Euro%202020">UEFA Euro 2020</a> qualifiers against Cyprus and Kazakhstan due to a hip injury. In October 2020, he was required to pull out of the squad for a Euro 2020 play-off semi-final against Israel after being in close contact with <a href="Stuart%20Armstrong">Stuart Armstrong</a>, who had tested positive for COVID-19. It was later confirmed by Armstrong, Tierney and <a href="Ryan%20Christie">Ryan Christie</a> that they had been playing video games in the same room.
Tierney provided three assists in a 4–0 win against the <a href="Faroe%20Islands%20national%20football%20team">Faroe Islands</a> on 31 March 2021, despite playing from a central defensive position.
